natural problem: Mr. Mendez awards extra credit on quizzes to his students with quiz grades that exceed the class mean. Given that 107 students take the same quiz, what is the largest number of students who can be awarded extra credit?
natural solution: It is not possible for all 107 to exceed the mean since the mean is always greater than or equal to the smallest element.

However 106 of the students can exceed the mean. For example, if 106 students get a 5 and the other student gets a 4, the mean is slightly less than 5 and all $\boxed{106}$ of the students that scored 5 will exceed the mean.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: nat and mean :: real and grades :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. x \<in> {1..107} \<longrightarrow> grades x \<ge> mean"
shows  "card {x \<in> {1..107}. grades x > mean} \<le> 106"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Mendez awards extra credit on quizzes to his students with quiz grades that exceed the class mean. Given that 107 students take the same quiz, what is the largest number of students who can be awarded extra credit? The final Answer is 106
 ### Proof
 It is not possible for all 107 to exceed the mean since the mean is always greater than or equal to the smallest element.
 However 106 of the students can exceed the mean. For example, if 106 students get a 5 and the other student gets a 4, the mean is slightly less than 5 and all $\boxed{106}$ of the students that scored 5 will exceed the mean.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: nat and mean :: real and grades :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. x \<in> {1..107} \<longrightarrow> grades x \<ge> mean"
shows  "card {x \<in> {1..107}. grades x > mean} \<le> 106"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a class of 107 students where every student scored at least the mean grade, find if it is possible that at most 106 students scored strictly more than the mean grade.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: nat
assumes h0 : "students = 107"
shows  "students - 1 = 106"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Mendez awards extra credit on quizzes to his students with quiz grades that exceed the class mean. Given that 107 students take the same quiz, what is the largest number of students who can be awarded extra credit? The final Answer is 106
 ### Proof
 It is not possible for all 107 to exceed the mean since the mean is always greater than or equal to the smallest element.
 However 106 of the students can exceed the mean. For example, if 106 students get a 5 and the other student gets a 4, the mean is slightly less than 5 and all $\boxed{106}$ of the students that scored 5 will exceed the mean.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: nat
assumes h0 : "students = 107"
shows  "students - 1 = 106"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If there are 107 students in a class and one student leaves, how many students are left? The final answer is 106.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: nat and mean quiz_grade :: real
assumes h0 : "students = 107"
and h1 : "\<forall>student. student \<le> students \<longrightarrow> quiz_grade student \<ge> mean"
shows  "\<exists>ec_students. ec_students = students - 1 \<and> (\<forall>student. student \<le> ec_students \<longrightarrow> quiz_grade student > mean)"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Mendez awards extra credit on quizzes to his students with quiz grades that exceed the class mean. Given that 107 students take the same quiz, what is the largest number of students who can be awarded extra credit? The final Answer is 106
 ### Proof
 It is not possible for all 107 to exceed the mean since the mean is always greater than or equal to the smallest element.
 However 106 of the students can exceed the mean. For example, if 106 students get a 5 and the other student gets a 4, the mean is slightly less than 5 and all $\boxed{106}$ of the students that scored 5 will exceed the mean.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: nat and mean quiz_grade :: real
assumes h0 : "students = 107"
and h1 : "\<forall>student. student \<le> students \<longrightarrow> quiz_grade student \<ge> mean"
shows  "\<exists>ec_students. ec_students = students - 1 \<and> (\<forall>student. student \<le> ec_students \<longrightarrow> quiz_grade student > mean)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There are 107 students in a class. If each student's quiz grade is at least the mean grade, is it possible to find a group of 106 students (one less than the total number of students) such that each student in this group has a quiz grade greater than the mean?

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students extra_credit :: nat
assumes h0 : "students = 107"
and h1 : "extra_credit < students"
shows  "extra_credit = 106"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Mendez awards extra credit on quizzes to his students with quiz grades that exceed the class mean. Given that 107 students take the same quiz, what is the largest number of students who can be awarded extra credit? The final Answer is 106
 ### Proof
 It is not possible for all 107 to exceed the mean since the mean is always greater than or equal to the smallest element.
 However 106 of the students can exceed the mean. For example, if 106 students get a 5 and the other student gets a 4, the mean is slightly less than 5 and all $\boxed{106}$ of the students that scored 5 will exceed the mean.
 *)

theorem
fixes students extra_credit :: nat
assumes h0 : "students = 107"
and h1 : "extra_credit < students"
shows  "extra_credit = 106"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: There are 107 students in a class. Find the maximum number of students who can receive extra credit if it's less than the total number of students. The final answer is 106.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 107"
shows  "n - 1 = 106"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Mendez awards extra credit on quizzes to his students with quiz grades that exceed the class mean. Given that 107 students take the same quiz, what is the largest number of students who can be awarded extra credit? The final Answer is 106
 ### Proof
 It is not possible for all 107 to exceed the mean since the mean is always greater than or equal to the smallest element.
 However 106 of the students can exceed the mean. For example, if 106 students get a 5 and the other student gets a 4, the mean is slightly less than 5 and all $\boxed{106}$ of the students that scored 5 will exceed the mean.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 107"
shows  "n - 1 = 106"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: What is the result when you subtract 1 from 107? The final answer is 106.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: nat and mean :: real
assumes h0 : "students = 107"
and h1 : "\<forall>student. student \<le> students \<longrightarrow> mean < student"
shows  "Max {student. student \<le> students \<and> mean < student} = 106"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Mendez awards extra credit on quizzes to his students with quiz grades that exceed the class mean. Given that 107 students take the same quiz, what is the largest number of students who can be awarded extra credit? The final Answer is 106
 ### Proof
 It is not possible for all 107 to exceed the mean since the mean is always greater than or equal to the smallest element.
 However 106 of the students can exceed the mean. For example, if 106 students get a 5 and the other student gets a 4, the mean is slightly less than 5 and all $\boxed{106}$ of the students that scored 5 will exceed the mean.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: nat and mean :: real
assumes h0 : "students = 107"
and h1 : "\<forall>student. student \<le> students \<longrightarrow> mean < student"
shows  "Max {student. student \<le> students \<and> mean < student} = 106"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: There are 107 students in a class. If the average score is less than each student's score, what is the maximum possible score? The final answer is 106.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and students :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 107"
and h1 : "\<forall> i < n. students i \<le> Max (students ` {i. i < n})"
shows  "card {i. i < n \<and> students i > Max (students ` {i. i < n})} \<le> 106"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Mendez awards extra credit on quizzes to his students with quiz grades that exceed the class mean. Given that 107 students take the same quiz, what is the largest number of students who can be awarded extra credit? The final Answer is 106
 ### Proof
 It is not possible for all 107 to exceed the mean since the mean is always greater than or equal to the smallest element.
 However 106 of the students can exceed the mean. For example, if 106 students get a 5 and the other student gets a 4, the mean is slightly less than 5 and all $\boxed{106}$ of the students that scored 5 will exceed the mean.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and students :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 107"
and h1 : "\<forall> i < n. students i \<le> Max (students ` {i. i < n})"
shows  "card {i. i < n \<and> students i > Max (students ` {i. i < n})} \<le> 106"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a class of 107 students, each student has a certain number of points. No student has more points than the maximum number of points scored by any student in the class. What is the maximum number of students who can score more than the maximum points? The final answer is 106.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_students :: nat and extra_credit_students :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_students = 107"
and h1 : "extra_credit_students \<le> total_students"
shows  "extra_credit_students = 106"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Mendez awards extra credit on quizzes to his students with quiz grades that exceed the class mean. Given that 107 students take the same quiz, what is the largest number of students who can be awarded extra credit? The final Answer is 106
 ### Proof
 It is not possible for all 107 to exceed the mean since the mean is always greater than or equal to the smallest element.
 However 106 of the students can exceed the mean. For example, if 106 students get a 5 and the other student gets a 4, the mean is slightly less than 5 and all $\boxed{106}$ of the students that scored 5 will exceed the mean.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_students :: nat and extra_credit_students :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_students = 107"
and h1 : "extra_credit_students \<le> total_students"
shows  "extra_credit_students = 106"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a class of 107 students, what is the maximum number of students that can receive extra credit? The final answer is 106.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_students extra_credit_students :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_students = 107"
shows  "extra_credit_students \<le> total_students - 1"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Mendez awards extra credit on quizzes to his students with quiz grades that exceed the class mean. Given that 107 students take the same quiz, what is the largest number of students who can be awarded extra credit? The final Answer is 106
 ### Proof
 It is not possible for all 107 to exceed the mean since the mean is always greater than or equal to the smallest element.
 However 106 of the students can exceed the mean. For example, if 106 students get a 5 and the other student gets a 4, the mean is slightly less than 5 and all $\boxed{106}$ of the students that scored 5 will exceed the mean.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_students extra_credit_students :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_students = 107"
shows  "extra_credit_students \<le> total_students - 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: There are 107 students in total. What is the maximum number of students who can receive extra credit? The final answer is 106.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: nat and class_mean :: real
assumes h0 : "students = 107"
and h1 : "\<forall> grade. grade > class_mean \<longrightarrow> (EX n. n \<le> students \<and> grade = n)"
shows  "EX max_students. max_students \<le> students \<and> max_students = students - 1"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Mr. Mendez awards extra credit on quizzes to his students with quiz grades that exceed the class mean. Given that 107 students take the same quiz, what is the largest number of students who can be awarded extra credit? The final Answer is 106
 ### Proof
 It is not possible for all 107 to exceed the mean since the mean is always greater than or equal to the smallest element.
 However 106 of the students can exceed the mean. For example, if 106 students get a 5 and the other student gets a 4, the mean is slightly less than 5 and all $\boxed{106}$ of the students that scored 5 will exceed the mean.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: nat and class_mean :: real
assumes h0 : "students = 107"
and h1 : "\<forall> grade. grade > class_mean \<longrightarrow> (EX n. n \<le> students \<and> grade = n)"
shows  "EX max_students. max_students \<le> students \<and> max_students = students - 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a class of 107 students, if every grade above the class average corresponds to a distinct number of students up to the total number of students in the class, find the maximum number of students that could have the same grade. The answer is 106.
